div.h2: What is Chemistry, and What Can Chemistry Do for You?
div.p:
One thing is certain: Once you start studying chemistry, all kinds of new questions will begin to occur to you. Let’s consider a typical day. Your alarm rings early, and you are groggy from sleep but eager to begin working on a chemistry assignment that’s coming due. Chemistry has taught you that there are interesting answers to questions you might once have considered silly and childish. Preparing tea, for example, now makes you wonder why the boiling water bubbles and produces steam while the teakettle retains its original shape. How do the tea leaves change the color of the water while the teabag remains as full and plump as ever? Why does sugar make your tea sweet, and why is the tea itself bitter?
You settle down with tea and newspaper, and the wondering continues. An article about methyl bromide, a widely used pesticide, says some scientists think it damages the ozone layer. What are methyl bromide and ozone? How does one destroy the other, and why should we care? How can we know if the ozone really is being depleted?
Later, as you drive to the library to get some books you need to complete that chemistry assignment, you wonder why gasoline burns and propels your car down the road. How does it pollute the air we breathe and what does the catalytic converter do to minimize the pollution? At the library, you wonder why some books that are hundreds of years old are still in good shape while other books that are only 50 years old have pages that are brown, brittle, and crumbling. Can the books with damaged pages be saved? Chemists can answer all these questions and others like them. They are scientists who study the structure of material substances—collectively called matter—and the changes that they undergo. Matter can be solid like sugar, liquid like water, or gaseous like the exhaust from your car’s tailpipe. Chemistry is often defined as the study of the structure and behavior of matter.
Chemists do a lot more than just answer questions. Industrial chemists are producing new materials to be used to build lighter and stronger airplanes, more environmentally friendly disposable cups, and more efficient anti‑pollution devices for your car. Pharmaceutical chemists are developing new drugs to fight cancer, control allergies, and even grow hair on bald heads.

Chemistry is the branch of science that deals with the properties, composition, and structure of matter, as well as the changes it undergoes. It is a fundamental science that plays a crucial role in our daily lives, from the food we eat to the medicine we take.

The study of chemistry begins with the atoms and molecules that make up matter. Atoms are the basic building blocks of matter and are made up of protons, neutrons, and electrons. The number of protons in an atom's nucleus determines its atomic number and, therefore, its identity as a unique element. For example, all carbon atoms have 6 protons, while all oxygen atoms have 8 protons.

Molecules are made up of two or more atoms that are chemically bonded together. The type of bond between atoms determines the properties of a molecule, such as its reactivity, solubility, and melting point. For example, the oxygen we breathe is made up of two oxygen atoms bonded together to form the molecule O2.

In addition to atoms and molecules, chemistry also deals with chemical reactions, which are processes that change the composition of matter. Chemical reactions can be represented by chemical equations, which use chemical formulas to show the reactants, products, and the stoichiometry of a reaction.

One of the most important branches of chemistry is organic chemistry, which deals with the study of carbon compounds. Carbon is unique among the elements in that it can form an almost infinite number of compounds, many of which are essential to life. Organic compounds are found in all living organisms and are used in a wide range of industrial and commercial products, such as fuels, plastics, and pharmaceuticals.

Analytical chemistry is another important branch of chemistry that deals with the identification and quantification of the chemical components of a sample. This can be done through a variety of techniques, including spectroscopy, chromatography, and microscopy.
Physical chemistry is the branch of chemistry that deals with the physical properties of matter and the energy changes that occur during chemical reactions. It is concerned with the principles that govern chemical reactions, such as thermodynamics and kinetics.

there are many subdisciplines of chemistry, such as biochemistry, environmental chemistry, and materials chemistry. Biochemistry deals with the chemical processes that occur in living organisms, while environmental chemistry focuses on the effects of human activities on the natural environment. Materials chemistry deals with the development of new materials and the study of their properties.

chemistry is a diverse and fascinating field that plays a vital role in our daily lives. From the food we eat to the medicine we take, chemistry is essential to our well-being. With the constant advancement of technology, the field of chemistry continues to make important contributions to society.
